def equals(self, other, *, reduce=False) 
1131    def equals(self, other, *, reduce=False):
1132        """`True` iff both dice have the same outcomes and quantities.
1133
1134        This is `False` if `other` is not a `Die`, even if it would convert
1135        to an equal `Die`.
1136
1137        Truth value does NOT matter.
1138
1139        If one die has a zero-quantity outcome and the other die does not
1140        contain that outcome, they are treated as unequal by this function.
1141
1142        The `==` and `!=` operators have a dual purpose; they return a die
1143        with a truth value determined by this method.
1144        Only dice returned by these methods have a truth value. The data of
1145        these dice is lazily evaluated since the caller may only be interested
1146        in the `Die` value or the truth value.
1147
1148        Args:
1149            reduce: If `True`, the dice will be reduced before comparing.
1150                Otherwise, e.g. a 2:2 coin is not `equals()` to a 1:1 coin.
1151        """
1152        if not isinstance(other, Die):
1153            return False
1154
1155        if reduce:
1156            return self.reduce().key_tuple() == other.reduce().key_tuple()
1157        else:
1158            return self.key_tuple() == other.key_tuple()

True iff both dice have the same outcomes and quantities.

This is False if other is not a Die, even if it would convert to an equal Die.

Truth value does NOT matter.

If one die has a zero-quantity outcome and the other die does not contain that outcome, they are treated as unequal by this function.

The == and != operators have a dual purpose; they return a die with a truth value determined by this method. Only dice returned by these methods have a truth value. The data of these dice is lazily evaluated since the caller may only be interested in the Die value or the truth value.

Args
  • reduce: If True, the dice will be reduced before comparing. Otherwise, e.g. a 2:2 coin is not equals() to a 1:1 coin.

class Population(abc.ABC, typing.Mapping[typing.Any, int]): 
 18class Population(ABC, Mapping[Any, int]):
 19    """A mapping from outcomes to `int` quantities.
 20
 21    Outcomes with each instance must be hashable and totally orderable.
 22
 23    Subclasses include `Die` and `Deck`.
 24    """
 25
 26    # Abstract methods.
 27
 28    @abstractmethod
 29    def keys(self) -> CountsKeysView:
 30        """The outcomes within the population in sorted order."""
 31
 32    @abstractmethod
 33    def values(self) -> CountsValuesView:
 34        """The quantities within the population in outcome order."""
 35
 36    @abstractmethod
 37    def items(self) -> CountsItemsView:
 38        """The (outcome, quantity)s of the population in sorted order."""
 39
 40    @property
 41    @abstractmethod
 42    def marginals(self):
 43        """A property that applies the `[]` operator to outcomes.
 44
 45        This is not performed elementwise on tuples, so that this can be used
 46        to slice tuples. For example, `mapping.marginals[:2]` will marginalize
 47        the first two elements of tuples.
 48        """
 49
 50    # Outcomes.
 51
 52    def outcomes(self) -> CountsKeysView:
 53        """The sorted outcomes of the mapping.
 54
 55        These are also the `keys` of the mapping.
 56        Prefer to use the name `outcomes`.
 57        """
 58        return self.keys()
 59
 60    @cached_property
 61    def _outcome_len(self) -> int | None:
 62        result = None
 63        for outcome in self.outcomes():
 64            try:
 65                if result is None:
 66                    result = len(outcome)
 67                elif len(outcome) != result:
 68                    return None
 69            except TypeError:
 70                return None
 71        return result
 72
 73    def outcome_len(self) -> int | None:
 74        """The common length of tuple outcomes.
 75
 76        This is `None` if outcomes are not tuples,
 77        or if there are tuples of different lengths.
 78        """
 79        return self._outcome_len
 80
 81    def is_empty(self) -> bool:
 82        """`True` iff this mapping has no outcomes. """
 83        return len(self) == 0
 84
 85    def min_outcome(self):
 86        """The least outcome."""
 87        return self.outcomes()[0]
 88
 89    def max_outcome(self):
 90        """The greatest outcome."""
 91        return self.outcomes()[-1]
 92
 93    def nearest_le(self, outcome):
 94        """The nearest outcome that is <= the argument.
 95
 96        Returns `None` if there is no such outcome.
 97        """
 98        index = bisect.bisect_right(self.outcomes(), outcome) - 1
 99        if index < 0:
100            return None
101        return self.outcomes()[index]
102
103    def nearest_ge(self, outcome):
104        """The nearest outcome that is >= the argument.
105
106        Returns `None` if there is no such outcome.
107        """
108        index = bisect.bisect_left(self.outcomes(), outcome)
109        if index >= len(self):
110            return None
111        return self.outcomes()[index]
112
113    # Quantities.
114
115    def quantities(self) -> CountsValuesView:
116        """The quantities of the mapping in sorted order.
117
118        These are also the `values` of the mapping.
119        Prefer to use the name `quantities`.
120        """
121        return self.values()
122
123    @cached_property
124    def _denominator(self) -> int:
125        return sum(self.values())
126
127    def denominator(self) -> int:
128        """The sum of all quantities (e.g. weights or duplicates).
129
130        For the number of unique outcomes, including those with zero quantity,
131        use `len()`.
132        """
133        return self._denominator
134
135    # Probabilities.
136
137    @cached_property
138    def _probabilities(self):
139        return tuple(v / self.denominator() for v in self.values())
140
141    def probabilities(self, percent: bool = False):
142        """Probability mass function. The probability of each outcome in order.
143
144        Args:
145            percent: If set, the results will be in percent (i.e. total of 100.0).
146                Otherwise, the total will be 1.0.
147        """
148        if percent:
149            return tuple(100.0 * x for x in self._probabilities)
150        else:
151            return self._probabilities
152
153    # Quantities.
154
155    def has_zero_quantities(self) -> bool:
156        """`True` iff `self` contains at least one outcome with zero quantity. """
157        return 0 in self.values()
158
159    @cached_property
160    def _quantities_le(self) -> Sequence[int]:
161        return tuple(itertools.accumulate(self.values()))
162
163    def quantities_le(self) -> Sequence[int]:
164        """The quantity <= each outcome in order. """
165        return self._quantities_le
166
167    @cached_property
168    def _quantities_ge(self) -> Sequence[int]:
169        return tuple(
170            itertools.accumulate(self.values()[:-1],
171                                 operator.sub,
172                                 initial=self.denominator()))
173
174    def quantities_ge(self) -> Sequence[int]:
175        """The quantity >= each outcome in order. """
176        return self._quantities_ge
177
178    @cached_property
179    def _probabilities_le(self):
180        return tuple(
181            quantity / self.denominator() for quantity in self.quantities_le())
182
183    def probabilities_le(self, percent: bool = False):
184        """The probability of rolling <= each outcome in order.
185
186        Also known as the cumulative distribution function (CDF),
187        though this term is ambigiuous whether it is < or <=.
188
189        Args:
190            percent: If set, the results will be in percent (i.e. total of 100.0).
191                Otherwise, the total will be 1.0.
192        """
193        if percent:
194            return tuple(100.0 * x for x in self._probabilities_le)
195        else:
196            return self._probabilities_le
197
198    @cached_property
199    def _probabilities_ge(self):
200        return tuple(
201            quantity / self.denominator() for quantity in self.quantities_ge())
202
203    def probabilities_ge(self, percent: bool = False):
204        """The probability of rolling >= each outcome in order.
205
206        Also known as the survival function (SF) or
207        complementary cumulative distribution function (CCDF),
208        though these term are ambigiuous whether they are is > or >=.
209
210        Args:
211            percent: If set, the results will be in percent (i.e. total of 100.0).
212                Otherwise, the total will be 1.0.
213        """
214        if percent:
215            return tuple(100.0 * x for x in self._probabilities_ge)
216        else:
217            return self._probabilities_ge
218
219    def quantity(self, outcome) -> int:
220        """The quantity of a single outcome, or 0 if not present. """
221        return self.get(outcome, 0)
222
223    def quantity_ne(self, outcome) -> int:
224        """The quantity != a single outcome. """
225        return self.denominator() - self.quantity(outcome)
226
227    def quantity_le(self, outcome) -> int:
228        """The quantity <= a single outcome. """
229        index = bisect.bisect_right(self.outcomes(), outcome) - 1
230        if index < 0:
231            return 0
232        return self.quantities_le()[index]
233
234    def quantity_lt(self, outcome) -> int:
235        """The quantity < a single outcome. """
236        index = bisect.bisect_left(self.outcomes(), outcome) - 1
237        if index < 0:
238            return 0
239        return self.quantities_le()[index]
240
241    def quantity_ge(self, outcome) -> int:
242        """The quantity >= a single outcome. """
243        index = bisect.bisect_left(self.outcomes(), outcome)
244        if index >= len(self):
245            return 0
246        return self.quantities_ge()[index]
247
248    def quantity_gt(self, outcome) -> int:
249        """The quantity > a single outcome. """
250        index = bisect.bisect_right(self.outcomes(), outcome)
251        if index >= len(self):
252            return 0
253        return self.quantities_ge()[index]
254
255    def probability(self, outcome):
256        """The probability of a single outcome. """
257        return self.quantity(outcome) / self.denominator()
258
259    # Scalar statistics.
260
261    def mode(self) -> tuple:
262        """A tuple containing the most common outcome(s) of the population.
263
264        These are sorted from lowest to highest.
265        """
266        return tuple(outcome for outcome, quantity in self.items()
267                     if quantity == self.modal_quantity())
268
269    def modal_quantity(self) -> int:
270        """The highest quantity of any single outcome. """
271        return max(self.quantities())
272
273    def kolmogorov_smirnov(self, other):
274        """KolmogorovSmirnov statistic. The maximum absolute difference between CDFs. """
275        a, b = icepool.align(self, other)
276        return max(
277            abs(a - b)
278            for a, b in zip(a.probabilities_le(), b.probabilities_le()))
279
280    def cramer_von_mises(self, other):
281        """Cramr-von Mises statistic. The sum-of-squares difference between CDFs. """
282        a, b = icepool.align(self, other)
283        return sum((a - b)**2
284                   for a, b in zip(a.probabilities_le(), b.probabilities_le()))
285
286    def median_left(self):
287        """The median, taking the lesser in case of a tie."""
288        return self.quantile_left(1, 2)
289
290    def median_right(self):
291        """The median, taking the greater in case of a tie."""
292        return self.quantile_right(1, 2)
293
294    def median(self):
295        """The median, taking the mean in case of a tie.
296
297        This will fail if the outcomes do not support division;
298        in this case, use `median_left` or `median_right` instead.
299        """
300        return self.quantile(1, 2)
301
302    def quantile_left(self, n: int, d: int = 100):
303        """The outcome `n / d` of the way through the CDF, taking the lesser in case of a tie."""
304        index = bisect.bisect_left(self.quantities_le(),
305                                   (n * self.denominator() + d - 1) // d)
306        if index >= len(self):
307            return self.max_outcome()
308        return self.outcomes()[index]
309
310    def quantile_right(self, n: int, d: int = 100):
311        """The outcome `n / d` of the way through the CDF, taking the greater in case of a tie."""
312        index = bisect.bisect_right(self.quantities_le(),
313                                    n * self.denominator() // d)
314        if index >= len(self):
315            return self.max_outcome()
316        return self.outcomes()[index]
317
318    def quantile(self, n: int, d: int = 100):
319        """The outcome `n / d` of the way through the CDF, taking the mean in case of a tie.
320
321        This will fail if the outcomes do not support division;
322        in this case, use `quantile_left` or `quantile_right` instead.
323        """
324        return (self.quantile_left(n, d) + self.quantile_right(n, d)) / 2
325
326    def mean(self):
327        return sum(outcome * quantity
328                   for outcome, quantity in self.items()) / self.denominator()
329
330    def variance(self):
331        """The population variance (not the sample variance)."""
332        mean = self.mean()
333        mean_of_squares = sum(
334            quantity * outcome**2
335            for outcome, quantity in self.items()) / self.denominator()
336        return mean_of_squares - mean * mean
337
338    def standard_deviation(self):
339        return math.sqrt(self.variance())
340
341    sd = standard_deviation
342
343    def standardized_moment(self, k: int):
344        sd = self.standard_deviation()
345        mean = self.mean()
346        ev = sum(p * (outcome - mean)**k
347                 for outcome, p in zip(self.outcomes(), self.probabilities()))
348        return ev / (sd**k)
349
350    def skewness(self):
351        return self.standardized_moment(3.0)
352
353    def excess_kurtosis(self):
354        return self.standardized_moment(4.0) - 3.0
355
356    # Joint statistics.
357
358    def covariance(self, i: int, j: int):
359        mean_i = self.marginals[i].mean()
360        mean_j = self.marginals[j].mean()
361        return sum((outcome[i] - mean_i) * (outcome[j] - mean_j) * quantity
362                   for outcome, quantity in self.items()) / self.denominator()
363
364    def correlation(self, i: int, j: int):
365        sd_i = self.marginals[i].standard_deviation()
366        sd_j = self.marginals[j].standard_deviation()
367        return self.covariance(i, j) / (sd_i * sd_j)
368
369    def sample(self):
370        """A single random sample from this population.
371
372        Note that this is always "with replacement" even for `Deck` since
373        instances are immutable.
374
375        This uses the standard `random` package and is not cryptographically
376        secure.
377        """
378        # We don't use random.choices since that is based on floats rather than ints.
379        r = random.randrange(self.denominator())
380        index = bisect.bisect_right(self.quantities_le(), r)
381        return self.outcomes()[index]
382
383    def format(self, format_spec: str, **kwargs) -> str:
384        """Formats this mapping as a string.
385
386        `format_spec` should start with the output format,
387        which is either `md` (Markdown) or `csv` (comma-separated values),
388        followed by a ':' character.
389
390        After this, zero or more columns should follow. Options are:
391
392        * `o`: Outcomes.
393        * `*o`: Outcomes, unpacked if applicable.
394        * `q==`, `q<=`, `q>=`: Quantities ==, <=, or >= each outcome.
395        * `p==`, `p<=`, `p>=`: Probabilities (0-1) ==, <=, or >= each outcome.
396        * `%==`, `%<=`, `%>=`: Probabilities (0%-100%) ==, <=, or >= each outcome.
397
398        Columns may optionally be separated using ` ` (space) or `|` characters.
399
400        The default is `'md:*o|q==|%=='`, with the quantity column being omitted
401        if any quantity exceeds 10**30.
402        """
403        if len(format_spec) == 0:
404            format_spec = 'md:*o'
405            if not self.is_empty() and self.modal_quantity() < 10**30:
406                format_spec += 'q=='
407            format_spec += '%=='
408
409        format_spec = format_spec.replace('|', '')
410
411        output_format, format_spec = format_spec.split(':')
412        if output_format == 'md':
413            return icepool.format.markdown(self, format_spec)
414        elif output_format == 'csv':
415            return icepool.format.csv(self, format_spec, **kwargs)
416        else:
417            raise ValueError(f"Unsupported output format '{output_format}'")
418
419    def __format__(self, format_spec: str) -> str:
420        return self.format(format_spec)
421
422    def __str__(self) -> str:
423        return f'{self}'

A mapping from outcomes to int quantities.

Outcomes with each instance must be hashable and totally orderable.

Subclasses include Die and Deck.

The (outcome, quantity)s of the population in sorted order.

marginals

A property that applies the [] operator to outcomes.

This is not performed elementwise on tuples, so that this can be used to slice tuples. For example, mapping.marginals[:2] will marginalize the first two elements of tuples.

407            format_spec += '%=='
408
409        format_spec = format_spec.replace('|', '')
410
411        output_format, format_spec = format_spec.split(':')
412        if output_format == 'md':
413            return icepool.format.markdown(self, format_spec)
414        elif output_format == 'csv':
415            return icepool.format.csv(self, format_spec, **kwargs)
416        else:
417            raise ValueError(f"Unsupported output format '{output_format}'")

Formats this mapping as a string.

format_spec should start with the output format, which is either md (Markdown) or csv (comma-separated values), followed by a ':' character.

After this, zero or more columns should follow. Options are:

  • o: Outcomes.
  • *o: Outcomes, unpacked if applicable.
  • q==, q<=, q>=: Quantities ==, <=, or >= each outcome.
  • p==, p<=, p>=: Probabilities (0-1) ==, <=, or >= each outcome.
  • %==, %<=, %>=: Probabilities (0%-100%) ==, <=, or >= each outcome.

Columns may optionally be separated using (space) or | characters.

The default is 'md:*o|q==|%==', with the quantity column being omitted if any quantity exceeds 10**30.

def from_cumulative_quantities( outcomes: Sequence, cumulative_quantities: Sequence[int], *, reverse: bool = False) -> icepool.Die: 
64def from_cumulative_quantities(outcomes: Sequence,
65                               cumulative_quantities: Sequence[int],
66                               *,
67                               reverse: bool = False) -> 'icepool.Die':
68    """Constructs a die from a sequence of cumulative quantities.
69
70    Args:
71        outcomes: The outcomes of the resulting die. Sorted order is recommended
72            but not necessary.
73        cumulative_quantities: The cumulative quantities (inclusive) of the
74            outcomes in the order they are given to this function.
75        reverse: Iff true, both of the arguments will be reversed. This allows
76            e.g. constructing using a survival distribution.
77    """
78
79    prev = 0
80    d = {}
81    for outcome, quantity in zip((reversed(outcomes) if reverse else outcomes),
82                                 (reversed(cumulative_quantities)
83                                  if reverse else cumulative_quantities)):
84        d[outcome] = quantity - prev
85        prev = quantity
86    return icepool.Die(d)

Constructs a die from a sequence of cumulative quantities.

Args
  • outcomes: The outcomes of the resulting die. Sorted order is recommended but not necessary.
  • cumulative_quantities: The cumulative quantities (inclusive) of the outcomes in the order they are given to this function.
  • reverse: Iff true, both of the arguments will be reversed. This allows e.g. constructing using a survival distribution.
def from_rv(rv, outcomes: Sequence[int | float], denominator: int, **kwargs) 
 89def from_rv(rv, outcomes: Sequence[int | float], denominator: int, **kwargs):
 90    """Constructs a die from a rv object (as `scipy.stats`).
 91    Args:
 92        rv: A rv object (as `scipy.stats`).
 93        outcomes: An iterable of `int`s or `float`s that will be the outcomes
 94            of the resulting die.
 95            If the distribution is discrete, outcomes must be `int`s.
 96        denominator: The denominator of the resulting die will be set to this.
 97        **kwargs: These will be provided to `rv.cdf()`.
 98    """
 99    if hasattr(rv, 'pdf'):
100        # Continuous distributions use midpoints.
101        midpoints = [(a + b) / 2 for a, b in zip(outcomes[:-1], outcomes[1:])]
102        cdf = rv.cdf(midpoints, **kwargs)
103        quantities_le = tuple(
104            int(round(x * denominator)) for x in cdf) + (denominator,)
105    else:
106        cdf = rv.cdf(outcomes, **kwargs)
107        quantities_le = tuple(int(round(x * denominator)) for x in cdf)
108    return from_cumulative_quantities(outcomes, quantities_le)

Constructs a die from a rv object (as scipy.stats).

Args
  • rv: A rv object (as scipy.stats).
  • outcomes: An iterable of ints or floats that will be the outcomes of the resulting die. If the distribution is discrete, outcomes must be ints.
  • denominator: The denominator of the resulting die will be set to this.
  • **kwargs: These will be provided to rv.cdf().
def align(*dice) -> tuple[icepool.Die, ...]: 
123def align(*dice) -> tuple['icepool.Die', ...]:
124    """Pads dice with zero quantities so that all have the same set of outcomes.

def reduce(func: Callable[[Any, Any], Any], dice, *, initial=None) 
154def reduce(func: Callable[[Any, Any], Any], dice, *, initial=None):
155    """Applies a function of two arguments cumulatively to a sequence of dice.
156
157    Analogous to
158    [`functools.reduce()`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functools.html#functools.reduce).
159
160    The function is applied non-elementwise to tuple outcomes.
161
162    Args:
163        func: The function to apply. The function should take two arguments,
164            which are an outcome from each of two dice.
165        dice: A sequence of dice to apply the function to, from left to right.
166        initial: If provided, this will be placed at the front of the sequence
167            of dice.
168    """
169    # Conversion to dice is not necessary since apply() takes care of that.
170    iter_dice = iter(dice)
171    if initial is not None:
172        result = initial
173    else:
174        result = next(iter_dice)
175    for die in iter_dice:
176        result = apply(func, result, die)
177    return result

  • dice: A sequence of dice to apply the function to, from left to right.
  • initial: If provided, this will be placed at the front of the sequence of dice.
def accumulate(func: Callable[[Any, Any], Any], dice, *, initial=None) 
180def accumulate(func: Callable[[Any, Any], Any], dice, *, initial=None):
181    """Applies a function of two arguments cumulatively to a sequence of dice, yielding each result in turn.
182
183    Analogous to
184    [`itertools.accumulate()`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/itertools.html#itertools.accumulate)
185    , though with no default function and
186    the same parameter order as `reduce()`.
187
188    The number of results is equal to the number of elements of `dice`, with
189    one additional element if `initial` is provided.
190
191    The function is applied non-elementwise to tuple outcomes.
192
193    Args:
194        func: The function to apply. The function should take two arguments,
195            which are an outcome from each of two dice.
196        dice: A sequence of dice to apply the function to, from left to right.
197        initial: If provided, this will be placed at the front of the sequence
198            of dice.
199    """
200    # Conversion to dice is not necessary since apply() takes care of that.
201    iter_dice = iter(dice)
202    if initial is not None:
203        result = initial
204    else:
205        try:
206            result = next(iter_dice)
207        except StopIteration:
208            return
209    yield result
210    for die in iter_dice:
211        result = apply(func, result, die)
212        yield result

Applies a function of two arguments cumulatively to a sequence of dice, yielding each result in turn.

Analogous to itertools.accumulate() , though with no default function and the same parameter order as reduce().

The number of results is equal to the number of elements of dice, with one additional element if initial is provided.

The function is applied non-elementwise to tuple outcomes.

Args
  • func: The function to apply. The function should take two arguments, which are an outcome from each of two dice.
  • dice: A sequence of dice to apply the function to, from left to right.
  • initial: If provided, this will be placed at the front of the sequence of dice.
def apply(func: Callable, *dice) -> icepool.Die: 
215def apply(func: Callable, *dice) -> 'icepool.Die':
216    """Applies `func(outcome_of_die_0, outcome_of_die_1, ...)` for all outcomes of the dice.
217
218    Example: `apply(lambda a, b: a + b, d6, d6)` is the same as d6 + d6.
219
220    `apply()` is flexible but not very efficient for more than two dice.
221    Instead of using more than two arguments:
222
223    * If the problem is easy to solve by considering one additional die at a
224        time, try using `reduce()` instead.
225    * If the problem is easy to solve by considering how many dice rolled each
226        outcome, one outcome at a time, try using
227        `icepool.Pool` and `icepool.OutcomeCountEvaluator`.
228    * If the order in which the dice are rolled is not important, you can use
229        `apply_sorted()`. This is less efficient than either of the above two,
230        but is still more efficient than `apply()`.
231
232    Args:
233        func: A function that takes one argument per input die and returns an
234            argument to `Die()`.
235        *dice: Any number of dice (or objects convertible to dice).
236            `func` will be called with all joint outcomes of `dice`, with one
237            argument per die.
238
239    Returns:
240        A die constructed from the outputs of `func` and the product of the
241        quantities of the dice.
242    """
243    if len(dice) == 0:
244        return icepool.Die([func()])
245    dice = tuple(icepool.Die([die]) for die in dice)
246    final_outcomes = []
247    final_quantities = []
248    for t in itertools.product(*(die.items() for die in dice)):
249        outcomes, quantities = zip(*t)
250        final_outcome = func(*outcomes)
251        final_quantity = math.prod(quantities)
252        if final_outcome is not icepool.Reroll:
253            final_outcomes.append(final_outcome)
254            final_quantities.append(final_quantity)
255
256    return icepool.Die(final_outcomes, final_quantities)

Applies func(outcome_of_die_0, outcome_of_die_1, ...) for all outcomes of the dice.

Example: apply(lambda a, b: a + b, d6, d6) is the same as d6 + d6.

apply() is flexible but not very efficient for more than two dice. Instead of using more than two arguments:

  • If the problem is easy to solve by considering one additional die at a time, try using reduce() instead.
  • If the problem is easy to solve by considering how many dice rolled each outcome, one outcome at a time, try using icepool.Pool and icepool.OutcomeCountEvaluator.
  • If the order in which the dice are rolled is not important, you can use apply_sorted(). This is less efficient than either of the above two, but is still more efficient than apply().
Args
  • func: A function that takes one argument per input die and returns an argument to Die().
  • *dice: Any number of dice (or objects convertible to dice). func will be called with all joint outcomes of dice, with one argument per die.
Returns

A die constructed from the outputs of func and the product of the quantities of the dice.

def apply_sorted(func: Callable, *dice) -> icepool.Die: 
259def apply_sorted(func: Callable, *dice) -> 'icepool.Die':
260    """Applies `func(lowest_outcome, next_lowest_outcome...)` for all sorted joint outcomes of the dice.
261
262    This is more efficient than `apply()` but still not very efficient.
263    Use `OutcomeCountEvaluator` instead if at all possible.
264
265    Args:
266        func: A function that takes one argument per input die and returns an
267            argument to `Die()`.
268        *dice: Any number of dice (or objects convertible to dice).
269            `func` will be called with all sorted joint outcomes of `dice`,
270            with one argument per die. All outcomes must be totally orderable.
271
272    Returns:
273        A die constructed from the outputs of `func` and the weight of rolling
274        the corresponding sorted outcomes.
275    """
276    pool = icepool.Pool(dice)
277    return icepool.enumerate_sorted(pool).sub(func, star=1)

Applies func(lowest_outcome, next_lowest_outcome...) for all sorted joint outcomes of the dice.

This is more efficient than apply() but still not very efficient. Use OutcomeCountEvaluator instead if at all possible.

Args
  • func: A function that takes one argument per input die and returns an argument to Die().
  • *dice: Any number of dice (or objects convertible to dice). func will be called with all sorted joint outcomes of dice, with one argument per die. All outcomes must be totally orderable.

Reroll = <SpecialValue.Reroll: 'Reroll'>

Indicates an outcome should be rerolled (with no max depth).

class OutcomeCountGenerator(abc.ABC): 
 20class OutcomeCountGenerator(ABC):
 21    """Abstract base class for incrementally generating `(outcome, counts, weight)`s.
 22
 23    These include dice pools (`Pool`) and card decks (`Deck`).
 24
 25    These generators can be evaluated by an `OutcomeCountEvaluator`.
 26    """
 27
 28    @abstractmethod
 29    def outcomes(self) -> Sequence:
 30        """The set of outcomes, in sorted order."""
 31
 32    @abstractmethod
 33    def _is_resolvable(self) -> bool:
 34        """`True` iff the generator is capable of producing an overall outcome.
 35
 36        For example, a dice pool will return `False` if it contains any dice
 37        with no outcomes.
 38        """
 39
 40    @abstractmethod
 41    def _generate_min(self, min_outcome) -> NextOutcomeCountGenerator:
 42        """Pops the min outcome from this generator if it matches the argument.
 43
 44        Yields:
 45            A generator with the min outcome popped.
 46            A tuple of counts for the min outcome.
 47            The weight for this many of the min outcome appearing.
 48
 49            If the argument does not match the min outcome, or this generator
 50            has no outcomes, only the single tuple `(self, 0, 1)` is yielded.
 51        """
 52
 53    @abstractmethod
 54    def _generate_max(self, max_outcome) -> NextOutcomeCountGenerator:
 55        """Pops the max outcome from this generator if it matches the argument.
 56
 57        Yields:
 58            A generator with the max outcome popped.
 59            A tuple of counts for the max outcome.
 60            The weight for this many of the max outcome appearing.
 61
 62            If the argument does not match the max outcome, or this generator
 63            has no outcomes, only the single tuple `(self, 0, 1)` is yielded.
 64        """
 65
 66    @abstractmethod
 67    def _estimate_direction_costs(self) -> tuple[int, int]:
 68        """Estimates the cost of popping from the min and max sides during an evaluation.
 69
 70        Returns:
 71            pop_min_cost: A positive `int`.
 72            pop_max_cost: A positive `int`.
 73        """
 74
 75    @abstractmethod
 76    def denominator(self) -> int:
 77        """The total weight of all paths through this generator."""
 78
 79    @abstractmethod
 80    def __eq__(self, other) -> bool:
 81        """All `OutcomeCountGenerator`s must implement equality."""
 82
 83    @abstractmethod
 84    def __hash__(self) -> int:
 85        """All `OutcomeCountGenerator`s must be hashable."""
 86
 87    def evaluate(self,
 88                 evaluator_or_func: 'icepool.OutcomeCountEvaluator' | Callable,
 89                 /) -> 'icepool.Die':
 90        """Evaluates this generator using the given `OutcomeCountEvaluator` or function.
 91
 92        Note that each `OutcomeCountEvaluator` instance carries its own cache;
 93        if you plan to use an evaluation multiple times,
 94        you may want to explicitly create an `OutcomeCountEvaluator` instance
 95        rather than passing a function to this method directly.
 96
 97        Args:
 98            func: This can be an `OutcomeCountEvaluator`, in which case it evaluates
 99                the generator directly.
100                Or it can be a `OutcomeCountEvaluator.next_state()`-like
101                function, taking in `state, outcome, *counts` and returning the
102                next state. In this case a temporary `WrapFuncEvaluator`
103                is constructed and used to evaluate this generator.
104        """
105        if not isinstance(evaluator_or_func, icepool.OutcomeCountEvaluator):
106            evaluator_or_func = icepool.WrapFuncEvaluator(evaluator_or_func)
107        return evaluator_or_func.evaluate(self)
108
109    def min_outcome(self):
110        return self.outcomes()[0]
111
112    def max_outcome(self):
113        return self.outcomes()[-1]
114
115    def sum(self) -> 'icepool.Die':
116        """Convenience method to simply sum the dice in this generator.
117
118        This uses `icepool.sum_pool`.
119
120        Returns:
121            A die representing the sum.
122        """
123        return icepool.evaluate_sum(self)
124
125    def sample(self) -> tuple[tuple, ...]:
126        """EXPERIMENTAL: A single random sample from this generator.
127
128        This uses the standard `random` package and is not cryptographically
129        secure.
130
131        Returns:
132            A sorted tuple of outcomes for each output of this generator.
133        """
134        if not self.outcomes():
135            raise ValueError('Cannot sample from an empty set of outcomes.')
136
137        min_cost, max_cost = self._estimate_direction_costs()
138
139        if min_cost < max_cost:
140            outcome = self.min_outcome()
141            generated = tuple(self._generate_min(outcome))
142        else:
143            outcome = self.max_outcome()
144            generated = tuple(self._generate_max(outcome))
145
146        cumulative_weights = tuple(
147            itertools.accumulate(g.denominator() * w for g, _, w in generated))
148        denominator = cumulative_weights[-1]
149        # We don't use random.choices since that is based on floats rather than ints.
150        r = random.randrange(denominator)
151        index = bisect.bisect_right(cumulative_weights, r)
152        # print(cumulative_weights, denominator, r, index)
153        popped_generator, counts, _ = generated[index]
154        head = tuple((outcome,) * count for count in counts)
155        if popped_generator.outcomes():
156            tail = popped_generator.sample()
157            return tuple(tuple(sorted(h + t)) for h, t, in zip(head, tail))
158        else:
159            return head

Abstract base class for incrementally generating (outcome, counts, weight)s.

These include dice pools (Pool) and card decks (Deck).

These generators can be evaluated by an OutcomeCountEvaluator.

def min_outcome(self) 
109    def min_outcome(self):
110        return self.outcomes()[0]
def max_outcome(self) 
112    def max_outcome(self):
113        return self.outcomes()[-1]

def sample(self) -> tuple[tuple, ...]: 
125    def sample(self) -> tuple[tuple, ...]:
126        """EXPERIMENTAL: A single random sample from this generator.
127
128        This uses the standard `random` package and is not cryptographically
129        secure.
130
131        Returns:
132            A sorted tuple of outcomes for each output of this generator.
133        """
134        if not self.outcomes():
135            raise ValueError('Cannot sample from an empty set of outcomes.')
136
137        min_cost, max_cost = self._estimate_direction_costs()
138
139        if min_cost < max_cost:
140            outcome = self.min_outcome()
141            generated = tuple(self._generate_min(outcome))
142        else:
143            outcome = self.max_outcome()
144            generated = tuple(self._generate_max(outcome))
145
146        cumulative_weights = tuple(
147            itertools.accumulate(g.denominator() * w for g, _, w in generated))
148        denominator = cumulative_weights[-1]
149        # We don't use random.choices since that is based on floats rather than ints.
150        r = random.randrange(denominator)
151        index = bisect.bisect_right(cumulative_weights, r)
152        # print(cumulative_weights, denominator, r, index)
153        popped_generator, counts, _ = generated[index]
154        head = tuple((outcome,) * count for count in counts)
155        if popped_generator.outcomes():
156            tail = popped_generator.sample()
157            return tuple(tuple(sorted(h + t)) for h, t, in zip(head, tail))
158        else:
159            return head

EXPERIMENTAL: A single random sample from this generator.

This uses the standard random package and is not cryptographically secure.

Returns

A sorted tuple of outcomes for each output of this generator.

class Pool(icepool.OutcomeCountGenerator): 
 40class Pool(OutcomeCountGenerator):
 41    """Represents a set of unordered dice, only distinguished by the outcomes they roll.
 42
 43    This should be used in conjunction with `OutcomeCountEvaluator` to generate a result.
 44    """
 45
 46    _post_roll_counts: tuple[int, ...]
 47    _dice: tuple[tuple['icepool.Die', int]]
 48
 49    def __new__(cls,
 50                dice: Mapping[Any, int] | Sequence,
 51                times: Sequence[int] | int = 1) -> 'Pool':
 52        """Public constructor for a pool.
 53
 54        Evaulation is most efficient when the dice are the same or same-side
 55        truncations of each other. For example, d4, d6, d8, d10, d12 are all
 56        same-side truncations of d12.
 57
 58        Args:
 59            dice: The dice to put in the pool. This can be one of the following:
 60
 61                * A sequence of dice.
 62                * A mapping of dice and how many of that die to put in the pool.
 63
 64                All outcomes within a pool must be totally orderable.
 65            times: Multiplies the number of times each element of `dice` will
 66                be put into the pool.
 67                `times` can either be a sequence of the same length as
 68                `outcomes` or a single `int` to apply to all elements of
 69                `outcomes`.
 70
 71        Raises:
 72            ValueError: If a bare `Deck` or `Die` argument is provided.
 73                A pool of a single `Die` should constructed as `Pool([die])`.
 74        """
 75        if isinstance(dice, Pool):
 76            if times == 1:
 77                return dice
 78            else:
 79                dice = dice._dice
 80
 81        if isinstance(dice, (icepool.Deck, icepool.Deal)):
 82            raise ValueError(
 83                f'A Pool cannot be constructed with a {type(dice).__name__} argument.'
 84            )
 85
 86        if isinstance(dice, icepool.Die):
 87            raise ValueError(
 88                'A Pool cannot be constructed with a Die argument. '
 89                'Use Pool([die]) or die.pool() to construct a pool of a single die.'
 90            )
 91
 92        dice, times = icepool.creation_args.itemize(dice, times)
 93        dice = tuple(icepool.Die([die]) for die in dice)
 94
 95        dice_counts: MutableMapping['icepool.Die', int] = defaultdict(int)
 96        for die, qty in zip(dice, times):
 97            dice_counts[die] += qty
 98        post_roll_counts = (1,) * sum(times)
 99        return cls._new_pool_from_mapping(dice_counts, post_roll_counts)
100
101    @classmethod
102    def _new_pool_from_mapping(cls, dice_counts: Mapping['icepool.Die', int],
103                               post_roll_counts: Sequence[int]) -> 'Pool':
104        """Creates a new pool.
105
106        Args:
107            dice_counts: A map from dice to rolls.
108            post_roll_counts: A tuple with length equal to the number of dice.
109        """
110        dice = tuple(
111            sorted(dice_counts.items(), key=lambda kv: kv[0].key_tuple()))
112        return new_pool_cached(
113            cls,  # type: ignore
114            dice,
115            post_roll_counts)
116
117    @classmethod
118    def _new_pool_from_tuple(cls, dice: tuple[tuple['icepool.Die', int]],
119                             post_roll_counts: tuple[int, ...]) -> 'Pool':
120        """Creates a new pool.
121
122        Args:
123            dice: A sorted tuple of (dice, count).
124            post_roll_counts: A tuple with length equal to the number of dice.
125        """
126        return new_pool_cached(
127            cls,  # type: ignore
128            dice,
129            post_roll_counts)

131    @cached_property
132    def _size(self) -> int:
133        return sum(count for _, count in self._dice)
134
135    def size(self) -> int:
136        """The number of dice in this pool, counting multiples of the same die."""
137        return self._size
138
139    def _is_resolvable(self) -> bool:
140        return all(not die.is_empty() for die, _ in self._dice)

142    @cached_property
143    def _denominator(self) -> int:
144        return math.prod(die.denominator()**count for die, count in self._dice)

146    def denominator(self) -> int:
147        return self._denominator

149    @cached_property
150    def _dice_tuple(self) -> tuple['icepool.Die', ...]:
151        return sum(((die,) * count for die, count in self._dice), start=())

153    @cached_property

155        return tuple(die for die, _ in self._dice)

157    def unique_dice(self) -> Collection['icepool.Die']:

161    @cached_property
162    def _outcomes(self) -> Sequence:
163        outcome_set = set(
164            itertools.chain.from_iterable(
165                die.outcomes() for die in self.unique_dice()))
166        return tuple(sorted(outcome_set))

169        """The union of outcomes among all dice in this pool."""
170        return self._outcomes

172    def _estimate_direction_costs(self) -> tuple[int, int]:
173        """Estimates the cost of popping from the min and max sides.
174
175        Returns:
176            pop_min_cost
177            pop_max_cost
178        """
179        return icepool.pool_cost.estimate_costs(self)

181    def post_roll_counts(self) -> tuple[int, ...]:
182        """The tuple indicating which dice in the pool will be counted.
183
184        The tuple has one element per die in the pool, from lowest roll to
185        highest roll.
186        """
187        return self._post_roll_counts
188
189    def set_post_roll_counts(self,
190                             post_roll_counts: int | slice | tuple[int, ...]):
191        """A pool with the selected dice counted after rolling and sorting.
192
193        Use `pool[post_roll_counts]` for the same effect as this method.
194
195        The dice are sorted in ascending order for this purpose,
196        regardless of which order the outcomes are evaluated in.
197
198        This is always an absolute selection on all `size` dice,
199        not a relative selection on already-selected dice,
200        which would be ambiguous in the presence of multiple or negative counts.
201
202        For example, here are some ways of selecting the two highest dice out of 5:
203
204        * `pool[3:5]`
205        * `pool[3:]`
206        * `pool[-2:]`
207        * `pool[..., 1, 1]`
208
209        These will also select the two highest dice out of 5, and will also
210        resize the pool to 5 dice first:
211
212        * `pool[3::5]`
213        * `pool[3:5:5]`
214        * `pool[-2::5]`
215        * `pool[0, 0, 0, 1, 1]`
216
217        These will count the highest as a positive and the lowest as a negative:
218
219        * `pool[-1, 0, 0, 0, 1]`
220        * `pool[-1, ..., 1]`
221
222        Args:
223            An `int`. This will count only the die at the specified index (once).
224                In this case, the result will be a `Die`, not a pool.
225            A `slice`. The selected dice are counted once each.
226                If provided, the third argument resizes the pool,
227                rather than being a step; however, this is only valid if the
228                pool consists of a single type of die.
229            A sequence of one `int` for each die.
230                Each die is counted that many times, which could be multiple or
231                negative times. This may resize the pool, but only if the
232                pool consists of a single type of die.
233
234                Up to one `Ellipsis` (`...`) may be used.
235                If an `Ellipsis` is used, the size of the pool won't change.
236                Instead, the `Ellipsis` will be replaced with a number of zero
237                counts, sufficient to maintain the current size of this pool.
238                This number may be "negative" if more `int`s are provided than
239                the size of the pool. Specifically:
240
241                * If `post_roll_counts` is shorter than `size`, the `Ellipsis`
242                    acts as enough zero counts to make up the difference.
243                    E.g. `pool[1, ..., 1]` on five dice would act as `pool[1, 0, 0, 0, 1]`.
244                * If `post_roll_counts` has length equal to `size`, the `Ellipsis` has no effect.
245                    E.g. `pool[1, ..., 1]` on two dice would act as `pool[1, 1]`.
246                * If `post_roll_counts` is longer than `size` and the `Ellipsis` is on one side,
247                    elements will be dropped from `post_roll_counts` on the side with the `Ellipsis`.
248                    E.g. `pool[..., 1, 2, 3]` on two dice would act as `pool[2, 3]`.
249                * If `post_roll_counts` is longer than `size` and the `Ellipsis`
250                    is in the middle, the counts will be as the sum of two
251                    one-sided `Ellipsis`.
252                    E.g. `pool[-1, ..., 1]` acts like `[-1, ...]` plus `[..., 1]`.
253                    On a pool consisting of a single single die this would have
254                    the -1 and 1 cancel each other out.
255
256        Raises:
257            ValueError:  If `post_roll_counts` would change the size of a pool
258                with more than one type of die, or if more than one `Ellipsis`
259                is used.
260        """
261        convert_to_die = isinstance(post_roll_counts, int)
262        post_roll_counts = post_roll_counts_tuple(self.size(), post_roll_counts)
263        if len(post_roll_counts) != self.size():
264            if len(self._dice) != 1:
265                raise ValueError(
266                    'Cannot change the size of a pool unless it has exactly one type of die.'
267                )
268            dice = Counts([(self._dice[0][0], len(post_roll_counts))])
269            result = Pool._new_pool_from_mapping(dice, post_roll_counts)
270        else:
271            result = Pool._new_pool_from_tuple(self._dice, post_roll_counts)
272        if convert_to_die:
273            return result.evaluate(lambda state, outcome, count: outcome
274                                   if count else state)
275        else:
276            return result
277
278    __getitem__ = set_post_roll_counts
279
280    @cached_property
281    def _min_outcome(self):
282        return min(die.min_outcome() for die in self.unique_dice())
283
284    def min_outcome(self):
285        """The min outcome among all dice in this pool."""
286        return self._min_outcome
287
288    @cached_property
289    def _max_outcome(self):
290        return max(die.max_outcome() for die in self.unique_dice())
291
292    def max_outcome(self):
293        """The max outcome among all dice in this pool."""
294        return self._max_outcome
295
296    def _generate_min(self, min_outcome) -> NextOutcomeCountGenerator:
297        """Pops the given outcome from this pool, if it is the min outcome.
298
299        Yields:
300            popped_pool: The pool after the min outcome is popped.
301            net_count: The number of dice that rolled the min outcome, after
302                accounting for post_roll_counts.
303            net_weight: The weight of this incremental result.
304        """
305        if not self.outcomes():
306            yield self, (0,), 1
307            return
308        generators = [
309            iter_die_pop_min(die, die_count, min_outcome)
310            for die, die_count in self._dice
311        ]
312        skip_weight = None
313        for pop in itertools.product(*generators):
314            total_hits = 0
315            result_weight = 1
316            next_dice_counts: MutableMapping[Any, int] = defaultdict(int)
317            for popped_die, misses, hits, weight in pop:
318                if not popped_die.is_empty():
319                    next_dice_counts[popped_die] += misses
320                total_hits += hits
321                result_weight *= weight
322            if total_hits == 0:
323                result_count = 0
324                popped_post_roll_counts = self.post_roll_counts()
325            else:
326                result_count = sum(self.post_roll_counts()[:total_hits])
327                popped_post_roll_counts = self.post_roll_counts()[total_hits:]
328            popped_pool = Pool._new_pool_from_mapping(next_dice_counts,
329                                                      popped_post_roll_counts)
330            if not any(popped_post_roll_counts):
331                # Dump all dice in exchange for the denominator.
332                skip_weight = (skip_weight or
333                               0) + result_weight * popped_pool.denominator()
334                continue
335
336            yield popped_pool, (result_count,), result_weight
337
338        if skip_weight is not None:
339            yield Pool([]), (sum(self.post_roll_counts()),), skip_weight
340
341    def _generate_max(self, max_outcome) -> NextOutcomeCountGenerator:
342        """Pops the given outcome from this pool, if it is the max outcome.
343
344        Yields:
345            popped_pool: The pool after the max outcome is popped.
346            net_count: The number of dice that rolled the max outcome, after
347                accounting for post_roll_counts.
348            net_weight: The weight of this incremental result.
349        """
350        if not self.outcomes():
351            yield self, (0,), 1
352            return
353        generators = [
354            iter_die_pop_max(die, die_count, max_outcome)
355            for die, die_count in self._dice
356        ]
357        skip_weight = None
358        for pop in itertools.product(*generators):
359            total_hits = 0
360            result_weight = 1
361            next_dice_counts: MutableMapping[Any, int] = defaultdict(int)
362            for popped_die, misses, hits, weight in pop:
363                if not popped_die.is_empty():
364                    next_dice_counts[popped_die] += misses
365                total_hits += hits
366                result_weight *= weight
367            if total_hits == 0:
368                result_count = 0
369                popped_post_roll_counts = self.post_roll_counts()
370            else:
371                result_count = sum(self.post_roll_counts()[-total_hits:])
372                popped_post_roll_counts = self.post_roll_counts()[:-total_hits]
373            popped_pool = Pool._new_pool_from_mapping(next_dice_counts,
374                                                      popped_post_roll_counts)
375            if not any(popped_post_roll_counts):
376                # Dump all dice in exchange for the denominator.
377                skip_weight = (skip_weight or
378                               0) + result_weight * popped_pool.denominator()
379                continue
380
381            yield popped_pool, (result_count,), result_weight
382
383        if skip_weight is not None:
384            yield Pool([]), (sum(self.post_roll_counts()),), skip_weight
385
386    def lowest(self, keep: int = 1, drop: int = 0) -> 'icepool.Die':
387        """The lowest outcome or sum of the lowest outcomes in the pool.
388
389        The args override any `post_roll_counts` of this pool.
390
391        Args:
392            keep: The number of lowest dice will be summed.
393            drop: This number of lowest dice will be dropped before keeping
394                dice to be summed.
395        """
396        if keep < 0:
397            raise ValueError(f'keep={keep} cannot be negative.')
398        if drop < 0:
399            raise ValueError(f'drop={drop} cannot be negative.')
400
401        start = min(drop, self.size())
402        stop = min(keep + drop, self.size())
403        return self[start:stop].sum()  # type: ignore
404
405    def highest(self, keep: int = 1, drop: int = 0) -> 'icepool.Die':
406        """The highest outcome or sum of the highest outcomes in the pool.
407
408        The args override any `post_roll_counts` of this pool.
409
410        Args:
411            keep: The number of highest dice will be summed.
412            drop: This number of highest dice will be dropped before keeping
413                dice to be summed.
414        """
415        if keep < 0:
416            raise ValueError(f'keep={keep} cannot be negative.')
417        if drop < 0:
418            raise ValueError(f'drop={drop} cannot be negative.')
419
420        start = self.size() - min(keep + drop, self.size())
421        stop = self.size() - min(drop, self.size())
422        return self[start:stop].sum()  # type: ignore
423
424    def __str__(self) -> str:
425        return (
426            f'Pool of {self.size()} dice with post_roll_counts={self.post_roll_counts()}\n'
427            + ''.join(f'  {repr(die)}\n' for die in self._dice_tuple))
428
429    @cached_property
430    def _key_tuple(self) -> tuple:
431        return Pool, self._dice, self._post_roll_counts
432
433    def __eq__(self, other) -> bool:
434        if not isinstance(other, Pool):
435            return False
436        return self._key_tuple == other._key_tuple
437
438    @cached_property
439    def _hash(self) -> int:
440        return hash(self._key_tuple)
441
442    def __hash__(self) -> int:
443        return self._hash

def set_post_roll_counts(self, post_roll_counts: int | slice | tuple[int, ...]) 
189    def set_post_roll_counts(self,
190                             post_roll_counts: int | slice | tuple[int, ...]):
191        """A pool with the selected dice counted after rolling and sorting.
192
193        Use `pool[post_roll_counts]` for the same effect as this method.
194
195        The dice are sorted in ascending order for this purpose,
196        regardless of which order the outcomes are evaluated in.
197
198        This is always an absolute selection on all `size` dice,
199        not a relative selection on already-selected dice,
200        which would be ambiguous in the presence of multiple or negative counts.
201
202        For example, here are some ways of selecting the two highest dice out of 5:
203
204        * `pool[3:5]`
205        * `pool[3:]`
206        * `pool[-2:]`
207        * `pool[..., 1, 1]`
208
209        These will also select the two highest dice out of 5, and will also
210        resize the pool to 5 dice first:
211
212        * `pool[3::5]`
213        * `pool[3:5:5]`
214        * `pool[-2::5]`
215        * `pool[0, 0, 0, 1, 1]`
216
217        These will count the highest as a positive and the lowest as a negative:
218
219        * `pool[-1, 0, 0, 0, 1]`
220        * `pool[-1, ..., 1]`
221
222        Args:
223            An `int`. This will count only the die at the specified index (once).
224                In this case, the result will be a `Die`, not a pool.
225            A `slice`. The selected dice are counted once each.
226                If provided, the third argument resizes the pool,
227                rather than being a step; however, this is only valid if the
228                pool consists of a single type of die.
229            A sequence of one `int` for each die.
230                Each die is counted that many times, which could be multiple or
231                negative times. This may resize the pool, but only if the
232                pool consists of a single type of die.
233
234                Up to one `Ellipsis` (`...`) may be used.
235                If an `Ellipsis` is used, the size of the pool won't change.
236                Instead, the `Ellipsis` will be replaced with a number of zero
237                counts, sufficient to maintain the current size of this pool.
238                This number may be "negative" if more `int`s are provided than
239                the size of the pool. Specifically:
240
241                * If `post_roll_counts` is shorter than `size`, the `Ellipsis`
242                    acts as enough zero counts to make up the difference.
243                    E.g. `pool[1, ..., 1]` on five dice would act as `pool[1, 0, 0, 0, 1]`.
244                * If `post_roll_counts` has length equal to `size`, the `Ellipsis` has no effect.
245                    E.g. `pool[1, ..., 1]` on two dice would act as `pool[1, 1]`.
246                * If `post_roll_counts` is longer than `size` and the `Ellipsis` is on one side,
247                    elements will be dropped from `post_roll_counts` on the side with the `Ellipsis`.
248                    E.g. `pool[..., 1, 2, 3]` on two dice would act as `pool[2, 3]`.
249                * If `post_roll_counts` is longer than `size` and the `Ellipsis`
250                    is in the middle, the counts will be as the sum of two
251                    one-sided `Ellipsis`.
252                    E.g. `pool[-1, ..., 1]` acts like `[-1, ...]` plus `[..., 1]`.
253                    On a pool consisting of a single single die this would have
254                    the -1 and 1 cancel each other out.
255
256        Raises:
257            ValueError:  If `post_roll_counts` would change the size of a pool
258                with more than one type of die, or if more than one `Ellipsis`
259                is used.
260        """
261        convert_to_die = isinstance(post_roll_counts, int)
262        post_roll_counts = post_roll_counts_tuple(self.size(), post_roll_counts)
263        if len(post_roll_counts) != self.size():
264            if len(self._dice) != 1:
265                raise ValueError(
266                    'Cannot change the size of a pool unless it has exactly one type of die.'
267                )
268            dice = Counts([(self._dice[0][0], len(post_roll_counts))])
269            result = Pool._new_pool_from_mapping(dice, post_roll_counts)
270        else:
271            result = Pool._new_pool_from_tuple(self._dice, post_roll_counts)
272        if convert_to_die:
273            return result.evaluate(lambda state, outcome, count: outcome
274                                   if count else state)
275        else:
276            return result

A pool with the selected dice counted after rolling and sorting.

Use pool[post_roll_counts] for the same effect as this method.

The dice are sorted in ascending order for this purpose, regardless of which order the outcomes are evaluated in.

This is always an absolute selection on all size dice, not a relative selection on already-selected dice, which would be ambiguous in the presence of multiple or negative counts.

For example, here are some ways of selecting the two highest dice out of 5:

  • pool[3:5]
  • pool[3:]
  • pool[-2:]
  • pool[..., 1, 1]

These will also select the two highest dice out of 5, and will also resize the pool to 5 dice first:

  • pool[3::5]
  • pool[3:5:5]
  • pool[-2::5]
  • pool[0, 0, 0, 1, 1]

These will count the highest as a positive and the lowest as a negative:

  • pool[-1, 0, 0, 0, 1]
  • pool[-1, ..., 1]
Args
  • An int. This will count only the die at the specified index (once). In this case, the result will be a Die, not a pool.
  • A slice. The selected dice are counted once each. If provided, the third argument resizes the pool, rather than being a step; however, this is only valid if the pool consists of a single type of die.

  • A sequence of one int for each die. Each die is counted that many times, which could be multiple or negative times. This may resize the pool, but only if the pool consists of a single type of die.

    Up to one Ellipsis (...) may be used. If an Ellipsis is used, the size of the pool won't change. Instead, the Ellipsis will be replaced with a number of zero counts, sufficient to maintain the current size of this pool. This number may be "negative" if more ints are provided than the size of the pool. Specifically:

    • If post_roll_counts is shorter than size, the Ellipsis acts as enough zero counts to make up the difference. E.g. pool[1, ..., 1] on five dice would act as pool[1, 0, 0, 0, 1].
    • If post_roll_counts has length equal to size, the Ellipsis has no effect. E.g. pool[1, ..., 1] on two dice would act as pool[1, 1].
    • If post_roll_counts is longer than size and the Ellipsis is on one side, elements will be dropped from post_roll_counts on the side with the Ellipsis. E.g. pool[..., 1, 2, 3] on two dice would act as pool[2, 3].
    • If post_roll_counts is longer than size and the Ellipsis is in the middle, the counts will be as the sum of two one-sided Ellipsis. E.g. pool[-1, ..., 1] acts like [-1, ...] plus [..., 1]. On a pool consisting of a single single die this would have the -1 and 1 cancel each other out.
Raises
  • ValueError: If post_roll_counts would change the size of a pool with more than one type of die, or if more than one Ellipsis is used.

def lowest(self, keep: int = 1, drop: int = 0) -> icepool.Die: 
386    def lowest(self, keep: int = 1, drop: int = 0) -> 'icepool.Die':

388
389        The args override any `post_roll_counts` of this pool.
