class OutcomeCountEvaluator(abc.ABC): 
 19class OutcomeCountEvaluator(ABC):
 20    """An abstract, immutable, callable class for evaulating one or more `OutcomeCountGenerator`s.
 21
 22    There is one abstract method to implement: `next_state()`.
 23    This should incrementally calculate the result given one outcome at a time
 24    along with how many of that outcome were produced.
 25
 26    An example sequence of calls, as far as `next_state()` is concerned, is:
 27
 28    1. `state = next_state(state=None, outcome=1, count_of_1s)`
 29    2. `state = next_state(state, 2, count_of_2s)`
 30    3. `state = next_state(state, 3, count_of_3s)`
 31    4. `state = next_state(state, 4, count_of_4s)`
 32    5. `state = next_state(state, 5, count_of_5s)`
 33    6. `state = next_state(state, 6, count_of_6s)`
 34    7. `outcome = final_outcome(state, *generators)`
 35
 36    A few other methods can optionally be overridden to further customize behavior.
 37
 38    It is not expected that subclasses of `OutcomeCountEvaluator`
 39    be able to handle arbitrary types or numbers of generators.
 40    Indeed, most are expected to handle only a fixed number of generators,
 41    and often even only generators with a particular type of die.
 42
 43    Instances cache all intermediate state distributions.
 44    You should therefore reuse instances when possible.
 45
 46    Instances should not be modified after construction
 47    in any way that affects the return values of these methods.
 48    Otherwise, values in the cache may be incorrect.
 49    """
 50
 51    @abstractmethod
 52    def next_state(self, state: Hashable, outcome, /, *counts: int) -> Hashable:
 53        """State transition function.
 54
 55        This should produce a state given the previous state, an outcome,
 56        and the number that outcome produced by each generator.
 57
 58        Within `evaluate()`, this will be called using only positional arguments.
 59        Thus, you may rename any of the arguments if you wish.
 60
 61        Make sure to handle the base case where `state is None`.
 62
 63        Args:
 64            state: A hashable object indicating the state before rolling the
 65                current outcome. If there was no previous outcome, this will be
 66                `None`.
 67            outcome: The current outcome.
 68                `next_state` will see all rolled outcomes in monotonic order;
 69                either ascending or descending depending on `direction()`.
 70                If there are multiple generators, the set of outcomes is the
 71                union of the outcomes of the invididual generators. All outcomes
 72                with nonzero  count will be visited. Outcomes with zero count
 73                may or may not be visited. If you need to enforce that certain
 74                outcomes are visited even if they have zero count, see
 75                `alignment()`.
 76            *counts: One `int` for each generator indicating how many of the current
 77                outcome were produced. If there are multiple
 78                generators, it's possible that some outcomes will not appear in
 79                all generators. In this case, the count for the generator(s)
 80                that do not have the outcome will be 0. Zero-quantity outcomes
 81                count as having that outcome.
 82
 83                Most subclasses will expect a fixed number of generators and
 84                can replace this variadic parameter with a fixed number of named
 85                parameters.
 86
 87        Returns:
 88            A hashable object indicating the next state.
 89            The special value `icepool.Reroll` can be used to immediately remove
 90            the state from consideration, effectively performing a full reroll.
 91        """
 92
 93    def final_outcome(self, final_state: Hashable, /,
 94                      *generators: icepool.OutcomeCountGenerator) -> Any:
 95        """Optional function to generate a final outcome from a final state.
 96
 97        Within `evaluate()`, this will be called using only positional arguments.
 98        Thus, you may rename any of the arguments if you wish.
 99
100        By default, the final outcome is equal to the final state.
101        Note that `None` is not a valid outcome for a die,
102        and if there are no outcomes, the final state will be `None`.
103        Subclasses that want to handle this case should explicitly define what
104        happens.
105
106        Args:
107            final_state: A state after all outcomes have been processed.
108            *generators: One or more `OutcomeCountGenerator`s being evaluated.
109                Most subclasses will expect a fixed number of generators and
110                can replace this variadic parameter with a fixed number of named
111                parameters.
112
113        Returns:
114            A final outcome that will be used as part of constructing the result die.
115            As usual for `Die()`, this could itself be a die or `icepool.Reroll`.
116        """
117        return final_state
118
119    def direction(self, *generators: icepool.OutcomeCountGenerator) -> int:
120        """Optional function to determine the direction in which `next_state()` will see outcomes.
121
122        The default is ascending order. This works well with mixed standard dice,
123        and other dice that differ only by right-truncation.
124
125        Args:
126            *generators: One or more `OutcomeCountGenerator`s being evaluated.
127                Most subclasses will expect a fixed number of generators and
128                can replace this variadic parameter with a fixed number of named
129                parameters.
130
131        Returns:
132            * > 0 if `next_state()` should always see the outcomes in ascending order.
133            * < 0 if `next_state()` should always see the outcomes in descending order.
134            * 0 if the order may be determined automatically.
135        """
136        return 1
137
138    def alignment(self,
139                  *generators: icepool.OutcomeCountGenerator) -> Collection:
140        """Optional function to specify an collection of outcomes that should always be given to `next_state()` even if they have zero count.
141
142        The default implementation returns `()`; this means outcomes with zero
143        count may or may not be seen by `next_state`.
144
145        If you want the outcomes seen by `next_state` to be consecutive
146        `int`s, you can set `alignment = icepool.OutcomeCountEvaluator.range_alignment`.
147        See `range_alignment()` below.
148        """
149        return ()
150
151    def range_alignment(
152            self,
153            *generators: icepool.OutcomeCountGenerator) -> Collection[int]:
154        """Example implementation of `alignment()` that produces consecutive `int` outcomes.
155
156        Set `alignment = icepool.OutcomeCountEvaluator.range_alignment` to use this.
157
158        Returns:
159            All `int`s from the min outcome to the max outcome among the generators,
160            inclusive.
161
162        Raises:
163            TypeError: if any generator has any non-`int` outcome.
164        """
165        if len(generators) == 0:
166            return ()
167
168        if any(
169                any(not isinstance(x, int)
170                    for x in generator.outcomes())
171                for generator in generators):
172            raise TypeError(
173                "range_alignment cannot be used with outcomes of type other than 'int'."
174            )
175
176        min_outcome = min(generator.min_outcome() for generator in generators)
177        max_outcome = max(generator.max_outcome() for generator in generators)
178        return range(min_outcome, max_outcome + 1)
179
180    @cached_property
181    def _cache(self) -> MutableMapping[Any, Mapping[Any, int]]:
182        """A cache of (direction, generators) -> weight distribution over states. """
183        return {}
184
185    def evaluate(
186        self, *generators: icepool.OutcomeCountGenerator | Mapping[Any, int] |
187        Sequence
188    ) -> 'icepool.Die':
189        """Evaluates generator(s).
190
191        You can call the `OutcomeCountEvaluator` object directly for the same effect,
192        e.g. `evaluate_sum(generator)` is an alias for `evaluate_sum.evaluate(generator)`.
193
194        Most evaluators will expect a fixed number of generators.
195        The union of the outcomes of the generator(s) must be totally orderable.
196
197        Args:
198            *generators: Each element may be one of the following:
199                * A `OutcomeCountGenerator`.
200                * A mappable mapping dice to the number of those dice.
201                * A sequence of arguments to create a `Pool`.
202
203        Returns:
204            A `Die` representing the distribution of the final score.
205        """
206
207        # Convert non-pool arguments to `Pool`.
208        converted_generators = tuple(
209            generator if isinstance(generator, icepool.OutcomeCountGenerator
210                                   ) else icepool.Pool(generator)
211            for generator in generators)
212
213        if not all(generator._is_resolvable()
214                   for generator in converted_generators):
215            return icepool.Die([])
216
217        algorithm, direction = self._select_algorithm(*converted_generators)
218
219        # We use a separate class to guarantee all outcomes are visited.
220        alignment = Alignment(self.alignment(*converted_generators))
221
222        dist = algorithm(direction, alignment, tuple(converted_generators))
223
224        final_outcomes = []
225        final_weights = []
226        for state, weight in dist.items():
227            outcome = self.final_outcome(state, *converted_generators)
228            if outcome is None:
229                raise TypeError(
230                    "None is not a valid final outcome. "
231                    "This may have resulted from supplying an empty generator to OutcomeCountEvaluator. "
232                    "If so, refrain from using empty generators, or override OutcomeCountEvaluator.final_outcome() to handle this case."
233                )
234            if outcome is not icepool.Reroll:
235                final_outcomes.append(outcome)
236                final_weights.append(weight)
237
238        return icepool.Die(final_outcomes, final_weights)
239
240    __call__ = evaluate
241
242    def _select_algorithm(
243            self,
244            *generators: icepool.OutcomeCountGenerator) -> tuple[Callable, int]:
245        """Selects an algorithm and iteration direction.
246
247        Returns:
248            * The algorithm to use (`_eval_internal*`).
249            * The direction in which `next_state()` sees outcomes.
250                1 for ascending and -1 for descending.
251
252        """
253        eval_direction = self.direction(*generators)
254
255        pop_min_costs, pop_max_costs = zip(*(
256            generator._estimate_direction_costs() for generator in generators))
257
258        pop_min_cost = math.prod(pop_min_costs)
259        pop_max_cost = math.prod(pop_max_costs)
260
261        # No preferred direction case: go directly with cost.
262        if eval_direction == 0:
263            if pop_max_cost <= pop_min_cost:
264                return self._eval_internal, 1
265            else:
266                return self._eval_internal, -1
267
268        # Preferred direction case.
269        # Go with the preferred direction unless there is a "significant"
270        # cost factor.
271
272        if PREFERRED_DIRECTION_COST_FACTOR * pop_max_cost < pop_min_cost:
273            cost_direction = 1
274        elif PREFERRED_DIRECTION_COST_FACTOR * pop_min_cost < pop_max_cost:
275            cost_direction = -1
276        else:
277            cost_direction = 0
278
279        if cost_direction == 0 or eval_direction == cost_direction:
280            # Use the preferred algorithm.
281            return self._eval_internal, eval_direction
282        else:
283            # Use the less-preferred algorithm.
284            return self._eval_internal_iterative, eval_direction
285
286    def _eval_internal(
287        self, direction: int, alignment: Alignment,
288        generators: tuple[icepool.OutcomeCountGenerator,
289                          ...]) -> Mapping[Any, int]:
290        """Internal algorithm for iterating in the more-preferred direction,
291        i.e. giving outcomes to `next_state()` from wide to narrow.
292
293        All intermediate return values are cached in the instance.
294
295        Arguments:
296            direction: The direction in which to send outcomes to `next_state()`.
297            alignment: As `alignment()`. Elements will be popped off this
298                during recursion.
299            generators: One or more `OutcomeCountGenerators`s to evaluate. Elements
300                will be popped off this during recursion.
301
302        Returns:
303            A dict `{ state : weight }` describing the probability distribution
304                over states.
305        """
306        cache_key = (direction, alignment, generators)
307        if cache_key in self._cache:
308            return self._cache[cache_key]
309
310        result: MutableMapping[Any, int] = defaultdict(int)
311
312        if all(not generator.outcomes()
313               for generator in generators) and not alignment.outcomes():
314            result = {None: 1}
315        else:
316            outcome, prev_alignment, iterators = _pop_generators(
317                direction, alignment, generators)
318            for p in itertools.product(*iterators):
319                prev_generators, counts, weights = zip(*p)
320                counts = tuple(itertools.chain.from_iterable(counts))
321                prod_weight = math.prod(weights)
322                prev = self._eval_internal(direction, prev_alignment,
323                                           prev_generators)
324                for prev_state, prev_weight in prev.items():
325                    state = self.next_state(prev_state, outcome, *counts)
326                    if state is not icepool.Reroll:
327                        result[state] += prev_weight * prod_weight
328
329        self._cache[cache_key] = result
330        return result
331
332    def _eval_internal_iterative(
333        self, direction: int, alignment: Alignment,
334        generators: tuple[icepool.OutcomeCountGenerator,
335                          ...]) -> Mapping[Any, int]:
336        """Internal algorithm for iterating in the less-preferred direction,
337        i.e. giving outcomes to `next_state()` from narrow to wide.
338
339        This algorithm does not perform persistent memoization.
340        """
341        if all(not generator.outcomes()
342               for generator in generators) and not alignment.outcomes():
343            return {None: 1}
344        dist: MutableMapping[Any, int] = defaultdict(int)
345        dist[None, alignment, generators] = 1
346        final_dist: MutableMapping[Any, int] = defaultdict(int)
347        while dist:
348            next_dist: MutableMapping[Any, int] = defaultdict(int)
349            for (prev_state, prev_alignment,
350                 prev_generators), weight in dist.items():
351                # The direction flip here is the only purpose of this algorithm.
352                outcome, alignment, iterators = _pop_generators(
353                    -direction, prev_alignment, prev_generators)
354                for p in itertools.product(*iterators):
355                    generators, counts, weights = zip(*p)
356                    counts = tuple(itertools.chain.from_iterable(counts))
357                    prod_weight = math.prod(weights)
358                    state = self.next_state(prev_state, outcome, *counts)
359                    if state is not icepool.Reroll:
360                        if all(not generator.outcomes()
361                               for generator in generators):
362                            final_dist[state] += weight * prod_weight
363                        else:
364                            next_dist[state, alignment,
365                                      generators] += weight * prod_weight
366            dist = next_dist
367        return final_dist

An abstract, immutable, callable class for evaulating one or more OutcomeCountGenerators.

There is one abstract method to implement: next_state(). This should incrementally calculate the result given one outcome at a time along with how many of that outcome were produced.

An example sequence of calls, as far as next_state() is concerned, is:

  1. state = next_state(state=None, outcome=1, count_of_1s)
  2. state = next_state(state, 2, count_of_2s)
  3. state = next_state(state, 3, count_of_3s)
  4. state = next_state(state, 4, count_of_4s)
  5. state = next_state(state, 5, count_of_5s)
  6. state = next_state(state, 6, count_of_6s)
  7. outcome = final_outcome(state, *generators)

A few other methods can optionally be overridden to further customize behavior.

It is not expected that subclasses of OutcomeCountEvaluator be able to handle arbitrary types or numbers of generators. Indeed, most are expected to handle only a fixed number of generators, and often even only generators with a particular type of die.

Instances cache all intermediate state distributions. You should therefore reuse instances when possible.

Instances should not be modified after construction in any way that affects the return values of these methods. Otherwise, values in the cache may be incorrect.

State transition function.

This should produce a state given the previous state, an outcome, and the number that outcome produced by each generator.

Within evaluate(), this will be called using only positional arguments. Thus, you may rename any of the arguments if you wish.

Make sure to handle the base case where state is None.

Args
  • state: A hashable object indicating the state before rolling the current outcome. If there was no previous outcome, this will be None.
  • outcome: The current outcome. next_state will see all rolled outcomes in monotonic order; either ascending or descending depending on direction(). If there are multiple generators, the set of outcomes is the union of the outcomes of the invididual generators. All outcomes with nonzero count will be visited. Outcomes with zero count may or may not be visited. If you need to enforce that certain outcomes are visited even if they have zero count, see alignment().

  • *counts: One int for each generator indicating how many of the current outcome were produced. If there are multiple generators, it's possible that some outcomes will not appear in all generators. In this case, the count for the generator(s) that do not have the outcome will be 0. Zero-quantity outcomes count as having that outcome.

    Most subclasses will expect a fixed number of generators and can replace this variadic parameter with a fixed number of named parameters.

Returns

A hashable object indicating the next state. The special value icepool.Reroll can be used to immediately remove the state from consideration, effectively performing a full reroll.

def final_outcome( self, final_state: Hashable, /, *generators: icepool.OutcomeCountGenerator) -> Any:

def alignment( self, *generators: icepool.OutcomeCountGenerator) -> Collection: 
138    def alignment(self,
139                  *generators: icepool.OutcomeCountGenerator) -> Collection:
140        """Optional function to specify an collection of outcomes that should always be given to `next_state()` even if they have zero count.
141
142        The default implementation returns `()`; this means outcomes with zero
143        count may or may not be seen by `next_state`.
144
145        If you want the outcomes seen by `next_state` to be consecutive
146        `int`s, you can set `alignment = icepool.OutcomeCountEvaluator.range_alignment`.
147        See `range_alignment()` below.
148        """
149        return ()

Optional function to specify an collection of outcomes that should always be given to next_state() even if they have zero count.

The default implementation returns (); this means outcomes with zero count may or may not be seen by next_state.

If you want the outcomes seen by next_state to be consecutive ints, you can set alignment = icepool.OutcomeCountEvaluator.range_alignment. See range_alignment() below.

def range_alignment( self, *generators: icepool.OutcomeCountGenerator) -> Collection[int]: 
151    def range_alignment(
152            self,
153            *generators: icepool.OutcomeCountGenerator) -> Collection[int]:
154        """Example implementation of `alignment()` that produces consecutive `int` outcomes.
155
156        Set `alignment = icepool.OutcomeCountEvaluator.range_alignment` to use this.
157
158        Returns:
159            All `int`s from the min outcome to the max outcome among the generators,
160            inclusive.
161
162        Raises:
163            TypeError: if any generator has any non-`int` outcome.
164        """
165        if len(generators) == 0:
166            return ()
167
168        if any(
169                any(not isinstance(x, int)
170                    for x in generator.outcomes())
171                for generator in generators):
172            raise TypeError(
173                "range_alignment cannot be used with outcomes of type other than 'int'."
174            )
175
176        min_outcome = min(generator.min_outcome() for generator in generators)
177        max_outcome = max(generator.max_outcome() for generator in generators)
178        return range(min_outcome, max_outcome + 1)

Example implementation of alignment() that produces consecutive int outcomes.

Set alignment = icepool.OutcomeCountEvaluator.range_alignment to use this.

Returns

All ints from the min outcome to the max outcome among the generators, inclusive.

Raises
  • TypeError: if any generator has any non-int outcome.
def evaluate( self, *generators: Union[icepool.OutcomeCountGenerator, Mapping[Any, int], Sequence]) -> icepool.Die: 
185    def evaluate(
186        self, *generators: icepool.OutcomeCountGenerator | Mapping[Any, int] |
187        Sequence
188    ) -> 'icepool.Die':
189        """Evaluates generator(s).
190
191        You can call the `OutcomeCountEvaluator` object directly for the same effect,
192        e.g. `evaluate_sum(generator)` is an alias for `evaluate_sum.evaluate(generator)`.
193
194        Most evaluators will expect a fixed number of generators.
195        The union of the outcomes of the generator(s) must be totally orderable.
196
197        Args:
198            *generators: Each element may be one of the following:
199                * A `OutcomeCountGenerator`.
200                * A mappable mapping dice to the number of those dice.
201                * A sequence of arguments to create a `Pool`.
202
203        Returns:
204            A `Die` representing the distribution of the final score.
205        """
206
207        # Convert non-pool arguments to `Pool`.
208        converted_generators = tuple(
209            generator if isinstance(generator, icepool.OutcomeCountGenerator
210                                   ) else icepool.Pool(generator)
211            for generator in generators)
212
213        if not all(generator._is_resolvable()
214                   for generator in converted_generators):
215            return icepool.Die([])
216
217        algorithm, direction = self._select_algorithm(*converted_generators)
218
219        # We use a separate class to guarantee all outcomes are visited.
220        alignment = Alignment(self.alignment(*converted_generators))
221
222        dist = algorithm(direction, alignment, tuple(converted_generators))
223
224        final_outcomes = []
225        final_weights = []
226        for state, weight in dist.items():
227            outcome = self.final_outcome(state, *converted_generators)
228            if outcome is None:
229                raise TypeError(
230                    "None is not a valid final outcome. "
231                    "This may have resulted from supplying an empty generator to OutcomeCountEvaluator. "
232                    "If so, refrain from using empty generators, or override OutcomeCountEvaluator.final_outcome() to handle this case."
233                )
234            if outcome is not icepool.Reroll:
235                final_outcomes.append(outcome)
236                final_weights.append(weight)
237
238        return icepool.Die(final_outcomes, final_weights)

Evaluates generator(s).

You can call the OutcomeCountEvaluator object directly for the same effect, e.g. evaluate_sum(generator) is an alias for evaluate_sum.evaluate(generator).

Most evaluators will expect a fixed number of generators. The union of the outcomes of the generator(s) must be totally orderable.

Args
  • *generators: Each element may be one of the following:
    • A OutcomeCountGenerator.
    • A mappable mapping dice to the number of those dice.
    • A sequence of arguments to create a Pool.
Returns

A Die representing the distribution of the final score.

class JointEvaluator(icepool.OutcomeCountEvaluator): 
420class JointEvaluator(OutcomeCountEvaluator):
421    """EXPERIMENTAL: An `OutcomeCountEvaluator` that jointly evaluates sub-evaluators on the same roll(s) of a generator.
422
423    It may be more efficient to write the joint evaluation directly; this is
424    provided as a convenience.
425    """
426
427    def __init__(self, *sub_evaluators: 'OutcomeCountEvaluator'):
428        self._sub_evaluators = sub_evaluators
429
430    def next_state(self, state, outcome, *counts: int):
431        """Runs `next_state` for all subevals.
432
433        The state is a tuple of the substates.
434        """
435        if state is None:
436            return tuple(
437                evaluator.next_state(None, outcome, *counts)
438                for evaluator in self._sub_evaluators)
439        else:
440            return tuple(
441                evaluator.next_state(substate, outcome, *counts)
442                for evaluator, substate in zip(self._sub_evaluators, state))
443
444    def final_outcome(self, final_state,
445                      *generators: icepool.OutcomeCountGenerator):
446        """Runs `final_state` for all subevals.
447
448        The final outcome is a tuple of the final suboutcomes.
449        """
450        return tuple(
451            evaluator.final_outcome(final_substate, *generators) for evaluator,
452            final_substate in zip(self._sub_evaluators, final_state))
453
454    def direction(self, *generators: icepool.OutcomeCountGenerator):
455        """Determines the common direction of the subevals.
456
457        Raises:
458            ValueError: If subevals have conflicting directions, i.e. some are
459                ascending and others are descending.
460        """
461        subdirections = tuple(
462            evaluator.direction(*generators)
463            for evaluator in self._sub_evaluators)
464        ascending = any(x > 0 for x in subdirections)
465        descending = any(x < 0 for x in subdirections)
466        if ascending and descending:
467            raise ValueError('Sub-evals have conflicting directions.')
468        elif ascending:
469            return 1
470        elif descending:
471            return -1
472        else:
473            return 0

EXPERIMENTAL: An OutcomeCountEvaluator that jointly evaluates sub-evaluators on the same roll(s) of a generator.

It may be more efficient to write the joint evaluation directly; this is provided as a convenience.

class Deck(abc.ABC, typing.Mapping[typing.Any, int]): 
 17class Deck(Population):
 18    """EXPERIMENTAL: Sampling without replacement. Quantities represent duplicates.
 19
 20    API and naming WIP.
 21    """
 22
 23    _data: Counts
 24    _deal: int
 25
 26    def __new__(cls,
 27                outcomes: Mapping[Any, int] | Sequence,
 28                times: Sequence[int] | int = 1) -> 'Deck':
 29        """Constructor for a deck.
 30
 31        Args:
 32            outcomes: The cards of the deck. This can be one of the following:
 33                * A `Mapping` from outcomes to quantities.
 34                * A sequence of outcomes.
 35
 36                Note that `Die` and `Deck` both count as `Mapping`s.
 37
 38                Each card may be one of the following:
 39                * A `Mapping` from outcomes to quantities.
 40                    The outcomes of the `Mapping` will be "flattened" into the
 41                    result. This option will be taken in preference to treating
 42                    the `Mapping` itself as an outcome even if the `Mapping`
 43                    itself is hashable and totally orderable. This means that
 44                    `Die` and `Deck` will never be outcomes.
 45                * A tuple of outcomes.
 46                    Any tuple elements that are `Mapping`s will expand the
 47                    tuple according to their independent joint distribution.
 48                    For example, `(d6, d6)` will expand to 36 ordered tuples
 49                    with dup 1 each. Use this carefully since it may create a
 50                    large number of outcomes.
 51                * Anything else will be treated as a single outcome.
 52                    Each outcome must be hashable, and the
 53                    set of outcomes must be totally orderable (after expansion).
 54                    The same outcome can appear multiple times, in which case
 55                    the corresponding quantities will be accumulated.
 56            times: Multiplies the number of times each element of `outcomes`
 57                will be put into the deck.
 58                `times` can either be a sequence of the same length as
 59                `outcomes` or a single `int` to apply to all elements of
 60                `outcomes`.
 61        """
 62        if isinstance(outcomes, Deck):
 63            if times == 1:
 64                return outcomes
 65            else:
 66                outcomes = outcomes._data
 67
 68        outcomes, times = icepool.creation_args.itemize(outcomes, times)
 69
 70        if len(outcomes) == 1 and times[0] == 1 and isinstance(
 71                outcomes[0], Deck):
 72            return outcomes[0]
 73
 74        data = icepool.creation_args.expand_args_for_deck(outcomes, times)
 75        return Deck._new_deck(data)
 76
 77    def unary_op_non_elementwise(self, op: Callable, *args, **kwargs) -> 'Deck':
 78        """As `unary_op()`, but not elementwise.
 79
 80        This is used for `marginals()`.
 81        """
 82        data: MutableMapping[Any, int] = defaultdict(int)
 83        for outcome, quantity in self.items():
 84            new_outcome = op(outcome, *args, **kwargs)
 85            data[new_outcome] += quantity
 86        return Deck(data)
 87
 88    @classmethod
 89    def _new_deck(cls, data: Counts) -> 'Deck':
 90        """Creates a new deck using already-processed arguments.
 91
 92        Args:
 93            data: At this point, this is a Counts.
 94        """
 95        self = super(Deck, cls).__new__(cls)
 96        self._data = data
 97        return self
 98
 99    def keys(self) -> CountsKeysView:
100        return self._data.keys()
101
102    def values(self) -> CountsValuesView:
103        return self._data.values()
104
105    def items(self) -> CountsItemsView:
106        return self._data.items()
107
108    def __getitem__(self, outcome) -> int:
109        return self._data[outcome]
110
111    def __iter__(self) -> Iterator:
112        return iter(self.keys())
113
114    def __len__(self) -> int:
115        return len(self._data)
116
117    size = icepool.Population.denominator
118
119    @cached_property
120    def _popped_min(self) -> tuple['Deck', int]:
121        return self._new_deck(self._data.remove_min()), self.quantities()[0]
122
123    def _pop_min(self) -> tuple['Deck', int]:
124        """A deck with the min outcome removed."""
125        return self._popped_min
126
127    @cached_property
128    def _popped_max(self) -> tuple['Deck', int]:
129        return self._new_deck(self._data.remove_max()), self.quantities()[-1]
130
131    def _pop_max(self) -> tuple['Deck', int]:
132        """A deck with the max outcome removed."""
133        return self._popped_max
134
135    def deal(self, *hand_sizes: int) -> 'icepool.Deal':
136        """Creates a `Deal` object from this deck.
137
138        See `Deal()` for details.
139        """
140        return icepool.Deal(self, *hand_sizes)
141
142    class _Marginals():
143        """Helper class for implementing `marginals()`."""
144
145        _deck: 'Deck'
146
147        def __init__(self, deck: 'Deck', /):
148            self._deck = deck
149
150        def __getitem__(self, dims, /) -> 'Deck':
151
152            return self._deck.unary_op_non_elementwise(operator.getitem, dims)
153
154    @property
155    def marginals(self):
156        """A property that applies the `[]` operator to outcomes.
157
158        This is not performed elementwise on tuples, so that this can be used
159        to slice tuples. For example, `deck.marginals[:2]` will marginalize the
160        first two elements of tuples.
161        """
162        return Deck._Marginals(self)
163
164    @cached_property
165    def _key_tuple(self) -> tuple:
166        return Deck, tuple(self.items())
167
168    def __eq__(self, other) -> bool:
169        if not isinstance(other, Deck):
170            return False
171        return self._key_tuple == other._key_tuple
172
173    @cached_property
174    def _hash(self) -> int:
175        return hash(self._key_tuple)
176
177    def __hash__(self) -> int:
178        return self._hash
179
180    def __repr__(self) -> str:
181        inner = ', '.join(
182            f'{outcome}: {quantity}' for outcome, quantity in self.items())
183        return type(self).__qualname__ + '({' + inner + '})'

Constructor for a deck.

Args

  • outcomes: The cards of the deck. This can be one of the following:

    • A Mapping from outcomes to quantities.
    • A sequence of outcomes.

    Note that Die and Deck both count as Mappings.

    Each card may be one of the following:

    • A Mapping from outcomes to quantities. The outcomes of the Mapping will be "flattened" into the result. This option will be taken in preference to treating the Mapping itself as an outcome even if the Mapping itself is hashable and totally orderable. This means that Die and Deck will never be outcomes.
    • A tuple of outcomes. Any tuple elements that are Mappings will expand the tuple according to their independent joint distribution. For example, (d6, d6) will expand to 36 ordered tuples with dup 1 each. Use this carefully since it may create a large number of outcomes.
    • Anything else will be treated as a single outcome. Each outcome must be hashable, and the set of outcomes must be totally orderable (after expansion). The same outcome can appear multiple times, in which case the corresponding quantities will be accumulated.
  • times: Multiplies the number of times each element of outcomes will be put into the deck. times can either be a sequence of the same length as outcomes or a single int to apply to all elements of outcomes.

132        """
133        return self._denominator

The sum of all quantities (e.g. weights or duplicates).

For the number of unique outcomes, including those with zero quantity, use len().

Creates a Deal object from this deck.

See Deal() for details.

marginals

A property that applies the [] operator to outcomes.

This is not performed elementwise on tuples, so that this can be used to slice tuples. For example, deck.marginals[:2] will marginalize the first two elements of tuples.

class Deal(icepool.OutcomeCountGenerator): 
 13class Deal(OutcomeCountGenerator):
 14    """EXPERIMENTAL: Represents an unordered deal of cards from a deck.
 15
 16    API and naming WIP.
 17    """
 18
 19    _deck: 'icepool.Deck'
 20    _hand_sizes: tuple[int, ...]
 21
 22    def __init__(self, deck: 'icepool.Deck', *hand_sizes: int):
 23        """Constructor.
 24
 25        For algorithmic reasons, you must pre-commit to the number of cards to
 26        deal for each hand.
 27
 28        Args:
 29            deck: The `Deck` to deal from.
 30            *hand_sizes: How many cards to deal. If multiple `hand_sizes` are
 31                provided, `OutcomeCountEvaluator.next_state` will recieve one count
 32                per hand in order. Try to keep the number of hands to a minimum
 33                as this can be computationally intensive.
 34        """
 35        if any(hand < 0 for hand in hand_sizes):
 36            raise ValueError('hand_sizes cannot be negative.')
 37        self._deck = deck
 38        self._hand_sizes = hand_sizes
 39        if self.total_cards_dealt() > self.deck().size():
 40            raise ValueError(
 41                'The total number of cards dealt cannot exceed the size of the deck.'
 42            )
 43
 44    def deck(self) -> 'icepool.Deck':
 45        """The deck the cards are dealt from."""
 46        return self._deck
 47
 48    def hand_sizes(self) -> tuple[int, ...]:
 49        """The number of cards dealt to each hand as a tuple."""
 50        return self._hand_sizes
 51
 52    def total_cards_dealt(self) -> int:
 53        """The total number of cards dealt."""
 54        return sum(self.hand_sizes())
 55
 56    def outcomes(self) -> CountsKeysView:
 57        """The outcomes of the deck in sorted order.
 58
 59        These are also the `keys` of the deck as a `Mapping`.
 60        Prefer to use the name `outcomes`.
 61        """
 62        return self.deck().outcomes()
 63
 64    def _is_resolvable(self) -> bool:
 65        return len(self.outcomes()) > 0
 66
 67    @cached_property
 68    def _denomiator(self) -> int:
 69        d_total = icepool.math.comb(self.deck().size(),
 70                                    self.total_cards_dealt())
 71        d_split = math.prod(
 72            icepool.math.comb(self.total_cards_dealt(), h)
 73            for h in self.hand_sizes()[1:])
 74        return d_total * d_split
 75
 76    def denominator(self) -> int:
 77        return self._denomiator
 78
 79    def _generate_common(self, popped_deck: 'icepool.Deck',
 80                         deck_count: int) -> NextOutcomeCountGenerator:
 81        """Common implementation for _generate_min and _generate_max."""
 82        min_count = max(
 83            0, deck_count + self.total_cards_dealt() - self.deck().size())
 84        max_count = min(deck_count, self.total_cards_dealt())
 85        for count_total in range(min_count, max_count + 1):
 86            weight_total = icepool.math.comb(deck_count, count_total)
 87            # The "deck" is the hand sizes.
 88            for counts, weight_split in iter_hypergeom(self.hand_sizes(),
 89                                                       count_total):
 90                popped_deal = Deal(
 91                    popped_deck,
 92                    *(h - c for h, c in zip(self.hand_sizes(), counts)))
 93                weight = weight_total * weight_split
 94                yield popped_deal, counts, weight
 95
 96    def _generate_min(self, min_outcome) -> NextOutcomeCountGenerator:
 97        if not self.outcomes() or min_outcome != self.min_outcome():
 98            yield self, (0,), 1
 99            return
100
101        popped_deck, deck_count = self.deck()._pop_min()
102
103        yield from self._generate_common(popped_deck, deck_count)
104
105    def _generate_max(self, max_outcome) -> NextOutcomeCountGenerator:
106        if not self.outcomes() or max_outcome != self.max_outcome():
107            yield self, (0,), 1
108            return
109
110        popped_deck, deck_count = self.deck()._pop_max()
111
112        yield from self._generate_common(popped_deck, deck_count)
113
114    def _estimate_direction_costs(self) -> tuple[int, int]:
115        result = len(self.outcomes()) * math.prod(self.hand_sizes())
116        return result, result
117
118    @cached_property
119    def _key_tuple(self) -> tuple:
120        return Deal, self.deck(), self.hand_sizes()
121
122    def __eq__(self, other) -> bool:
123        if not isinstance(other, Deal):
124            return False
125        return self._key_tuple == other._key_tuple
126
127    @cached_property
128    def _hash(self) -> int:
129        return hash(self._key_tuple)
130
131    def __hash__(self) -> int:
132        return self._hash
133
134    def __repr__(self) -> str:
135        return type(
136            self
137        ).__qualname__ + f'({repr(self.deck())}, hand_sizes={self.hand_sizes()})'
138
139    def __str__(self) -> str:
140        return f'Deal of hand_sizes={self.hand_sizes()} from deck:\n' + str(
141            self.deck())
